thread.title: METALS-Zinc soars 10 pct, fuelling metals surge after Glencore cuts output
thread.title_full: METALS-Zinc soars 10 pct, fuelling metals surge after Glencore cuts output | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: METALS-Zinc soars 10 pct, fuelling metals surge after Glencore cuts output
text:
* Glencore to cut 500,000 tonnes of annual zinc production
* Markets relieved that Fed seen hold off raising rates (Recasts, adds comment/detail, updates prices, changes dateline)
By Maytaal Angel
LONDON, Oct 9 (Reuters) - Zinc surged 10 percent on Friday and other base metals soared after commodities giant Glencore said it would slash its zinc output by a third, sparking a short covering rally across the board.
Glencore said it will cut 500,000 tonnes of annual zinc production, equivalent to around 4 percent of global supply, in its latest response to weak commodities prices.
The miner has already pledged copper and coal production cuts in response to multi-year low prices.
Adding fuel to the metals rally, oil prices rose, making commodity basket funds that include metals more attractive, while the dollar slid on the view that the U.S. central bank is in no rush to raise interest rates.
"This (Glencore move) is big, its much bigger than the move in copper, it shifts the needle substantially. The rally is not going to all peter out, though having said that the jump today is in large part cause of short covering," said BNP Paribas strategist Stephen Briggs.
Zinc mine supply had already been set to shrink given the closure of MMG's huge Century mine in Australia and Lisheen in Ireland this year.
London Metal Exchange zinc rose 10.2 percent to $1,837 at 0929 GMT, its highest price in a month and its biggest single-day gain on Reuters data records, which go back to mid-2005.
Lead, which is often mined alongside zinc, surged 6 percent at one point to its highest since late July at $1,774, copper and aluminium gained 4 percent while nickel surged more than 5 percent to hit a month high.
The price rally is set to be a shot in the arm for the beleaguered metals industry, many of whose members are heading for London for the annual LME Week celebrations which start on Monday.
Elsewhere, the minutes of the Federal Reserve's meeting on Thursday revealed the extent to which policymakers are concerned that a global economic slowdown might threaten the U.S. economic outlook.
For metals, concerns persist about the growth slowdown in China, which consumes about half the world's copper.
Senior metals executives in China expect most base metals will face tepid demand there next year as growth slows in the world's second largest economy, although there is some hope appetite will strengthen later in the year.
